description.narrative: The activities are geared at combatting corruption by strengthening the capacity of the Yemeni Parliament to monitor and control the incoming foreign aid flows into Yemen and their allocation by the Yemeni government: - The training of a group (5 parliamentarians, 6 managers/secretaries involved in the Parliamen-tarian Development, Financial and Services Committees and 4 members of Yemen PACon the procedures and the methodology of external donors in Yemen and on the monitoring and evaluation of their funding (grants, loans) and activities. - The setting up of an internal support group in Yemeni Parliament of 15 persons (committee staff, administrators) that will be selected by the parliamentarian Development, Financial and Services Committees (5 representatives from each committee) that will also be trained on external donors procedures/methodology and their monitoring/evaluation in order to assist and support the parliamentary group. - The setting up of a database with information on all external financial support for Yemen and to make this information readily available to all interested parties electronically. - The presentation of a draft External Aid Law to theYemeni Parliament that will guarantee the legal role of the Yemeni Parliament with regard to the monitoring, control of all fundingby external donors. - The formulation of quarterly oversight reports (every 3 months) on loans and grants to Yemen that will be prepared by parliamentary group with the help of experts. These reports are available for all interested parties and will be published on the website of the organization. - The formulation of two half- yearly reports (every 6 months) on loans and grants to Yemen thatwill be prepared by the parliamentary with the help of experts. These reports are available for all interested parties and will be published on the website of the organization. Once a year an accumulative annual report (1,500 copies) will be edited, printed and distributed. - The two half-yearly reports will be discussed during two workshops (30 participants each) in Sana’a for different stakeholders (CSOs, civil society, media) to set up lobby and advocacy activities around external funding issues.

participating-org.narrative: After the establishment of the Organization of Arab Parliamentarians against Corruption (ARPAC) in November 2004 in Beirut, plans were made together with Yemeni Members of Parliament to combat corruption in Yemen. However, it was difficult to implement a specificprogram for Yemen within a regional organization as ARPAC and therefore the organisation Yemen Parliamentarians Against Corruption (Yemen PAC) was officially registered as an NGO in December 2005 in Sana’a. The organization has been able to obtain a license from the government to conduct its work in the year 2011 after the Arab Youth Spring in Yemen it was registered under No. 514, formally issued by the Ministry of Labor and Social Affairs. Since 2012 the organization began to mainstream gender in its activities, and ithas been employing females for the first time since the founding of the organization. At the project level, Yemen PAC has required of all the projects implemented in the year 2012, that the participation of women will be 30% within all of the components of its projects. Although the beginning is modest the organisation will continue this approach to enhance the participation of women in all its programs up to 50%. Yemen PAC is currently implementing a program regarding institutional strengthening to qualify for the ISO 9001 certificate and it is expected to complete this program in 2014.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation

description.narrative: no. of partner organisations with stronger capacity for monitoring governments and private sector on obligations and duties in their budget (income and expenditure) with specific attention to impact on women
